title: ‘Uncharted’ Review: Better Left in Beta
sub_head: Tom Holland stars in a shambles of a movie based on the videogame series.
body:
If less is more, “Uncharted” must be a masterpiece. It’s bloodless, heartless, joyless, sexless and, with one exception, charmless. The exception is Tom Holland, but what’s he doing in a slapdash action adventure adapted from a videogame? Making money, of course—gamers will flock. Still, he’s a movie star for good reason, a refreshingly earnest presence with impressive acting chops. This is a concatenation of digital effects dedicated to the proposition that Newton got his laws of motion all wrong, and that physical objects, including human beings, can perform whatever gyrations a computer can concoct.
The source in question is Sony’s videogame series of the same name. In its theatrical version, directed by Ruben Fleischer, the treasure-hunt story gets fully under way when one thief recruits another. The recruit, Nathan Drake (Mr. Holland), is street-smart yet innocent, a combination that the actor actually pulls off. (Nathan and his brother, Sam, who’s presumed to be dead, are descendants of the English explorer Sir Francis Drake.) The recruiter, a cheerful treasure hunter named Victor “Sully” Sullivan, is played by Mark Wahlberg, who looks like he wishes he were elsewhere. The main action pits the two of them against a team led by Santiago Moncada (Antonio Banderas), a ruthless treasure hunter, in a search for a legendary trove of gold that was amassed by Ferdinand Magellan and acquired, then lost, by the House of Moncada half a millennium ago.
